Document Sources.Sourced Statement: According to U.S. Census data, just over half of those renters spend 90% of their income or more on rent.
California landlords earn 7 cents of profit on average for every dollar of rent.
Document Sources.Source Justification: recent data from the National Apartment Association, a trade group for property owners

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Equitable Rent Rent Stabilization Standards in the City of Los Angeles
Document Sources.Source Justification: the city-commissioned report; the independent economic analysis; the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study; the independent analysis; the report; LAist obtained the report through a public records request.; The report; the report; the report; The report; the report; the report; the report; The report; the report; the report; the report; the report; the report; the report; the report; the report; the report; The Economic Roundtable report; the report; the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Last October, Councilmembers Bob Blumenfield and Hugo Soto-Martinez put forward a motion calling for a fresh look at the city’s decades-old formula for setting annual limits on rent hikes.
Last October, Councilmembers Bob Blumenfield and Hugo Soto-Martinez put forward a motion calling for a fresh look at the city’s decades-old formula for setting annual limits on rent hikes.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the council members who requested the report be commissioned

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “What [the report] is trying to do is make a PR effort to lay the groundwork to chip away at what little ability landlords have in L.A. to be able to raise rents and be able to keep up with their costs,” Yukelson said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are plenty of owners out there who have had their renters in place for many years,” Yukelson said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “They're way below market. And they're having trouble today keeping up with the growing costs of insurance, maintenance and supplies.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Small landlords are able to maintain their profits and draw income above their expenses — they haven't been overly burdened by rent stabilization,” said Christina Boyar, a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The report shows that rent costs exceeding what tenants can pay is a primary cause of homelessness,” Boyar said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We are obviously in a homelessness crisis in L.A., and if this formula isn't updated soon, more folks will just fall into homelessness.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Daniel Flaming, president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report, said he didn’t have a good answer for why the report was kept under wraps.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I think when it's a politically contentious issue, there are attempts to manage the conversation,” Flaming said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The substance of the report is final. It was submitted as a final report and accepted by the city as a final work product.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Sharon Sandow, a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department, told LAist last week the document was still a “draft report,” and they didn't have a specific date lined up for its release.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are several rounds of revisions left to go before this report is considered final,” Sandow said in an email.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Economic Roundtable is under contract to complete this report through January 2025 — though clearly we hope to have it finalized before then.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The cost of electricity is just going to continue going up,” Yukelson with the Apartment Association said.

If the city stops landlords who provide electricity from raising rents an additional 1% per year, he said, “The next tenant is going to have to pay that burden, because the rents are going to have to go up.”

On balance, Flaming said the report shows that L.A.’s policies diverge significantly from how other California cities handle rent control. He said the utility surcharge in particular seems “arbitrary.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The Los Angeles ceiling and floor are atypically high for rent-controlled cities,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Among cities that have elected to control rents — and not all cities have — Los Angeles appears to be tilted toward landlords.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: In an email reacting to the Economic Roundtable report, Soto-Martínez told LAist, “As we await the finalized version of this report, it’s heartening to see so much data supporting the policy changes that renters have been demanding — especially when it comes to preventing excessive rent increases that can devastate working families.”

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: This May, the Economic Roundtable, the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study, submitted its report to the L.A. Housing Department.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: “Economic Roundtable is under contract to complete this report through January 2025 — though clearly we hope to have it finalized before then.”

When LAist first requested the report, officials told a reporter the study was not subject to disclosure under the California Public Records Act, saying there was an exemption for “deliberative process.”
